div.l: ¶ Oure oost answerde ⁊and seide I gᵃraunte it the
Now telle on Roger loke þat it be gode
For many a paste hast þou leten bloode
And mony a Iakk a doủere hast þou soold
That hath ben twies hoot ⁊and twies coold
Of mony pylgryme hastow cristes curs
For of thi persely ȝet fare þei þe wors
Þat þei haue eten with thi stubbil goos
For in þi shoppe is mony a fle loos
Now telle on gentil Roger by þi name
But ȝit I pray the be not wroth for game
A man may say ful sothe in game and play
Thou sayst ful soth quod Rogger by my fay
But soth play quade play as þe flemyng saith
And þerfore henry baillif by thi faithe
Be þou not wroth or we deꝑparten here
Thogh þat my tale be of an Osteliere
But natheles I wil not tellen it ȝete
But or we part I wis þᵘou shalt be quyte
And therwith alle loghe ⁊and made chere
And saide his tale as ȝe shal after here
Here endith the ꝓprolog͗e //
And begynneth þe þe tale
A Prentys whilom dwelled in oure citee
And of a craft of vitalere was he
Gaillard he was as golfynche in þe schawe
Broun as a bery a ꝓpropre short felawe
With lokkes blake I kempt ful fetisly
Daunce he kouthe so wel and Iolyly
Þat he was clepid perkyn reuelouo
He was as fulle of loue and ꝑparamour
As is þe hyve ful of hony swete
Welle was the wenche with him myght mete
At eủery bridale wolde he synge ⁊and hoppe
He loued bette þe tauerne þan þe shoppe
¶ For whan þer any ryding was in chepe
Out of the shoppe thider wold he lepe
Til þat he had al þe sight I seyn
And daunced wel wold he not come a geyn
And gedrid him a meny of his sort
To hoppe and syng ⁊and make suche disport
And þere thei setten steuen for to mete
